div.p: THE RESURRECTION Re≈øcued from the Souldiers Calumnies, In Two SERMONS Preached at St. Maries in oxon.

div.head: The Stationer to the Reader.
div.p:
IT being the con≈øtant Cu≈øtom to u≈øher all ≈øorts of Books into the World with a Preface, I thought good to give this ≈øhort
Account of the two following Sermons: Their Authour Dr. Robert Jones (a man ≈øufficiently eminent for his extraordinary parts) was appointed to preach a Re≈øurrection-Sermon on Ea≈øter-day in St. Maries Church in Oxford; which be performed with very
great applau≈øe and ≈øatisfaction. Yet having delivered ≈øomething in the Repetition-Sermon which did not plea≈øe the nicer Palates of ≈øome of his Auditors, he was oblig'd by the Principalls of the ∆≤ niver≈øity, to make a Recantation-Sermon; which how ingeniou≈øly
he performed, I leave the intelligent Reader after a ≈øerious peru≈øall to judge and cen≈øure.

div.head: THE REPETITION SERMON.

q.p: His Di≈øciples came by night and stole him away while we ≈ølept.

div.p:
WHat's the be≈øt News abroad? So we mu≈øt begin: 'Tis the Garb (les novelles) the grand ≈øalute, and common Preface to all our
talk. And the news goes not as things are in them≈øelves, but as mensfancies are fa≈øhioned, as ≈øome lu≈øt to report, and others to believe: The ≈øame relation ≈øhall goe for true or fal≈øe, according to the key wherein mens minds are tuned; but chiefly as they ≈øtand diver≈øe in Religion, ≈øo they feign and affect different News. By their News ye may know their Religion, and by their Religion fore-know their News. This week the Spani≈øh Match goes forward, and Bethleem Gabors Troups are broken; and the next week Bethleem Gabors Troups goe forward, and the Spani≈øh Match is broken. The Catholique is of the
Spani≈øh match, and the Prote≈øtant of re≈øtoring the Palatinate; and each party think that the ≈øafety of the Church and ≈øucce≈øs of religion depends upon the event of one or other, and therefore they cro≈øs and counter-tell each others news. Titius came from London ye≈øterday, and he ≈øayes that the new Chappel at St. James is quite fini≈øhed: Caius came thence but this morning, and then there was no ≈øuch thing on building. Fal≈øe news follows true at the heels, and oftentimes out≈øtrips it.

Thus goes the Chronicle-news, the talke of the factius and pragmatick; but the
Chri≈øtian news, the talke of the faithful is ≈øpent in Euangelio, in hearing and telling ≈øome good news of their Saviour: and now all the talk is of his Re≈øurrection. The Chri≈øtian current goes, News from Mount Calvary, the ≈øixteenth day of Ni≈øan, in the year thirty four, old ≈øtyle; as the three holy Matrons deliver it at the eighth ver≈øe of this Chapter. But ≈øince there are certain Souldiers arrived, and they ≈øay there was no ≈øuch matter as the Re≈øurrection, 'twas but a gull put upon the world by his Di≈øciples; for it fares with ≈øpiritual news as with temporal, it is variou≈øly and contrarily related, till the
fal≈øe controls the true. And as our modern News comes neither from the Court nor the Camp, nor from the place where things are acted, but is forged in Conventicles by Prie≈øts, or in ≈øome Pauls A≈ø≈øembly, or ≈øuch like place; and the divulge committed to ≈øome vigilant and watchful tongue: So it is with the News of the Nonre≈øurrection; it came not from Mount Calvary, but the Prie≈øts are the Authors of it, at the eleventh ver≈øe; and at the twelveth, they frame and mould it to the mouth of the Watch. The Divulgers, men of double credit, they know the truth, for they are of the Watch, and they
will not lye, for they are Souldiers; nay, they will maintain it, for they are Knights, Milites, Knights of the Po≈øt, they are hired to ≈øay, ≈øaying, and they did ≈øay, His Di≈øciples came by night and ≈øtole him away whil≈øt we ≈ølept.

The words ≈øo plain, they need no opening. May it plea≈øe you that I make three Cur≈øories over them; One for the Souldiers, another for the Di≈øciples, and the third for our Saviour. In the two former we will beat the point pro and con, and in the latter reconcile it, for that's the fa≈øhion al≈øo. No error ≈øo ab≈øurd but finds a Patron,
nor Truth ≈øo ≈øound but meets with an Adver≈øary, nor point controverted but the oppo≈øite tenent may be reconciled; be they di≈øtant as Heaven and Hell, as incompatible as Jew and Chri≈øtian, yet they ≈øhall meet with a Moderator, and a cogging di≈øtinction ≈øhall ≈øtate the que≈øtion on the ab≈øurder ≈øide. Fir≈øt then for the Souldiers, who≈øe Cur≈øory hath no parts, that's not the Souldiers manner, but yet is ≈øprinkled with ab≈øurdities, that's the manner of the Watch. They ≈øpeak partly as they fight, voluntarily, and partly as they watch, ≈øupinely. And thus they begin their talk:

Ye men and people of Judah and Jeru≈øalem, This Je≈øus of Nazareth was a very Jugler, a neat Compiler of Impostures, pretended title to the crown of Judah, made him≈øelf the Me≈øsias and the Son of God, brought ≈øuch ≈øtrange opinions as would turn the whole world out of bias; having no proof from ≈øen≈øe or rea≈øon for his Novelties, he would needs confirm them by miracles; and in the worlds eye he ≈øeemed to do wonders, though his works were indeed but meer delu≈øions, wrought by ≈ølight of hand, hocus pocus. All which was ≈øo manife≈øtly di≈øcovered, that to ≈øtop the
current of ≈øuch fal≈øe coin, my Lord Pre≈øident was forced to nail him to the Cro≈ø≈øe for a Counterfeit. His Ma≈øter-trick was that of the Re≈øurrection, whereof he fore≈øpake in his life-time: for he was no ordinary dealer, but would make his Cunning to ≈øurvive his per≈øon, and dur≈øt fore-≈øay ≈øo. To put this piece in Execution, he entertained a rabble of Ruffians, whom he termed his Di≈øciples, as all Plotters have Partners: The≈øe he in≈øtructed in the game while he lived, and they were to play it when he was dead. The li≈øt of his Di≈øciples con≈øi≈øted of Men and Women; for in all crafty carriages
there lyes a Womans part. The men were to perform all manner of fact, and the women, who≈øe activity lies in their tongue, were to report the miracle.

The High-prie≈øts and ≈øome of the Sanedrim being wi≈øe to apprehend, and wary to prevent the dangerous con≈øequences hereof, procured a warrant from the Pre≈øident to ≈øeal up the Tomb, and place a Watch there; and we were the parties appointed to guard it. The Charge we underwent required good ≈øervice, for his Di≈øciples were common Night-walkers like their Ma≈øter, notable Cutters, and carried as
much courage as cunning; ≈øuch tall fellows with their weapons, that they made it but a ≈øleight either to with≈øtand or a≈ø≈øault a whole multitude, and dur≈øt do any thing in their Ma≈øters behalf. The other night, when we apprehended him in Geth≈øemane, we were mo≈øt of the lu≈øtie≈øt fellows in Jeru≈øalem, and pretty well appointed, yet they ≈øtood to it ≈øtoutly, made a tall fray, and ≈øometimes put us to the wor≈øt: At the fir≈øt On-≈øet we were all knock'd down, and at our Recovery, Rabbi Malchus, a follower of the Highprie≈øts company and our Captain, was ≈øingled out by one of their ≈øide, a Sayler he
≈øeemed, who with his whinyard lopt off one of his ears, and had the blow light right, it would have cleft him down to the twi≈øt. Nay they were all Bravers, and their bloody mind was ≈øeen upon Judas I≈øcariot, one of their own company, who becau≈øe he was our Bloodhound to ≈øent their Ma≈øter out, they per≈øecuted the poor wretch till they had paunch'd him; for not far from their walk he was found hang'd with his guts about his heels. And for their bloody pranks that way, the place begins to bear the name of Aceldama, the bloody field.

For the exploit of his re≈øurrection, they had the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of their fellow-≈øhe-di≈øciples, night hou≈øe-wives too, for they were hovering about the Sepulchre from the dead of the night till the morning, and were as the Counter-watch to give notice of ≈øome advantage to the Di≈øciples, who lay not far off, ≈øome where above ground, while their ma≈øter was under it. All the day-time they ≈øtir not for fear of Pa≈ø≈øengers, frequenting to and fro in the gardens and walks about Mount Calvary; it being both Sabbath and Pa≈ø≈øeover; but in the night they took their opportunity by this means: We had been
extreamly over-travell'd, both to apprehend and guard him, fir≈øt, to the Highprie≈øt, next to the Pre≈øident; from him to Herod, and back again; then to his arraignment, then to his Execution and ever ≈øince at his grave; ≈øo turbulent the man was, that his very dead body would not lye ≈øtill and be quiet. This over-watching, ≈øeconded with the darkne≈øs of the night, and coldne≈ø≈øe of the ayre, ca≈øt us into a heavy ≈øleep; thereupon the women give the watch-word to the Di≈øciples, who immediately do exhumate his body; and while they tran≈ølate and bury it el≈øewhere, the women trot into the Town, and
bruit it abroad that their Ma≈øter is ri≈øen.

And the credulous City is partly inclined to believe the Legerdemain; they are willing to frame their faith and build their ≈øalvation upon a flying gull, rai≈øed by three way-going women, gadling Go≈øsips that came from Galilee; One of them notorious, ≈øo divelli≈øh that there came ≈øeven divells out of her, how many ≈øtaid behind God knows; it is like ≈øhe was ≈øo full, there was room for no more; and by her ye may gue≈øs at her companions. Con≈øider of it; the matter is of moment, a main point of State, that
concerns your own Nation: We are but ≈øtrangers, and no farther intere≈ø≈øed then for the truths ≈øake to ≈øpeak it; and therefore be advi≈øed whether ye will rely herein upon the word of a woman, or upon the faith and reputation of a Souldier. And here the Souldier puts up, he ≈øheaths his malicious and bla≈øphemous tongue, more ≈øharp and deadly then his ≈øword, and gives our Saviour a wound more mortal far then tho≈øe upon the Cro≈øs; they did but put him in a trance, ≈øu≈øpend his life for a day or two, at the mo≈øt but kill his Humanity; but this would murther his Divinity, and dead his Immortality,
it would nullifie the Go≈øpel, and fru≈øtrate all our Faith: for, If Chri≈øt be not ri≈øen (≈øaith S. Paul) then is our preaching vain, and your faith is al≈øo vain. And therefore I come to my ≈øecond Cur≈øory, For his Di≈øciples ≈øtole him away by night.

Herein we will deal Chri≈øtianly and civilly, not give the lye to the Souldiers, foul words to the Watch: But yet we may ≈øay, that their tale hath no truth in any point of it, but a meer ≈øaying, Saying, ≈øay ye. They ≈øay not of them≈øelves, but as the Priests taught them; they knew they ≈øaid fal≈øe, and therefore our ≈øaying to
the contrary will ea≈øily obtain. And therein we follow not the Random of their roving, but take the ≈øum of their ≈øaying, as it is here ≈øet down by the Holy Gho≈øt, giving it order and parts. The words then may ea≈øily be taken Judiciarily, in form of an accu≈øation, and then Morally they are Calumny; the Souldiers either not heard, or not practi≈øed the doctrine of John Bapti≈øt, Accu≈øe no man fal≈øely. Or they may be taken popularly, in form of a report or rumour, and then morally they are a meer gull or ≈ølander. In what ≈øen≈øe ≈øoever, there are three parties wronged in them; The Di≈øciples,
our Saviour, and the Souldiers them≈øelves. The Di≈øciples here are tax'd of theft, that they - ≈øhould come by night, and ≈øteal away their Ma≈øter: Our Saviour of Impotency and Impo≈øture, that he neither could nor did ri≈øe from the dead, but was conveyed away by his Di≈øciples: And the Souldiers of capital negligence, that they were a≈øleep. In the Cur≈øory then for the Di≈øciples, may ye plea≈øe that I lay down three plain Contradictories ro the words of the Text, as they lie in order: Fir≈øt, the Di≈øciples came not hither by night. Secondy, he was not ≈øtole away. Thirdly, the Souldiers were not a≈øleep. For proof
of each whereof there are no cogent demon≈øtrations in nature Qu√≤d ≈øint; ≈øingle voluntary actions that leave no evident effect, admit it not. We preach not before Jews and Infidels, to whom this doctrine is ≈øcandalous and fool ≈øhne≈øs; but the ≈øimplehearted Christian, the willing hearer ≈øhall have rationall probabilities, and per≈øwa≈øive arguments, ≈øufficient to convey belief into a heart illuminated, and prepared by grace for it. For the fir≈øt then, His Di≈øciples came not by night.

The body moves not voluntarily, unle≈øs the motion be grounded upon the Will;
≈øo that when the influence of the Will upon the external members is either intercepted or fru≈øtrated by any forreign accident, the body hardly admits of going and comming. The heart, and fir≈øt mover of the Di≈øciples, was now mated and ≈øet up by a Lea≈øe of impetuous pa≈ø≈øions. All tho≈øe Violents of the Soul which have mi≈øchiefs for their Objects, and are immediately di≈øtractive to the Patient that endures them, as ≈øorrow, fear and de≈øpair, did now wholly po≈ø≈øe≈øs them: Extreme ≈øorrow for their Ma≈øters pre≈øent ≈øufferings, as much fear for their own future danger, and their like de≈øpaire for their
fore hoped happine≈ø≈øe. Their ≈øen≈øes ≈øeel the ≈øorrow, their fear torments their fancies, and their memory maintains their de≈øpair; their whole ≈øoul ≈øo a≈ø≈øaulted, that there wanted nothing but a Fever to make them quite frantick. And Peter came neer to that, ≈øo di≈øtracted, that for his Masters ≈øake fir≈øt he will needs fight, then he flyes away; anon again he follows after him, at length he for≈øwears him, and in the end goes out and cries. In this mode he is carried up and down, till he layes a clog on his con≈øcience, that would hold him work enough without coming to Mount Calvary. The ca≈øe of his
other fellows might be as bad, or wor≈øe, although the Scripture be therein ≈øilent. Thus far they go all with Peter, that they ≈øleep, and flye, and follow after off.

But when their Ma≈øter was pa≈øt all recovery, then each pa≈ø≈øion plaid his part to hinder all humour from comming to Mount Calvary. Their ≈øorrow contracts, and clo≈øeth them up in Jeru≈øalem: Sorrow loves to be private and lurk in a corner. Fear kept them within doors: Fear dare not go abroad, e≈øpecially in the night, if ≈øhe do, it is to flie a danger, not to invite it. And to De≈øpair all bu≈øine≈øs mu≈øt
yield: de≈øpair will not ≈øtir in her own behalf, unle≈øs to do her ≈øelf a mi≈øchief, but of any other ≈øhe is quite carele≈øs. To ≈øay then they came by night, makes it but the more unlikely. They could not watch one hour with him in Geth≈øemane when it concerned his life, while there was yet hope to vindicate him from the Cro≈øs; and can they now watch with him a whole night when he was dead and buried? If they were for a nights exploit, they would have done it the night before, when there was a fairer opportuuity, and greater ≈øecurity. They now had no more means this night, but
more danger. When they they went to Geth≈øemane, they had but two Swords in all, and were there di≈øarmed of them; but one coat apeece, and ≈øome ≈øtript of that; no weapon to a≈ø≈øault, nor armour to defend. Fit furniture, and fair voyage for poor Fi≈øhermen to make to Mount Calvary in a dark night, to affront the Roman Watch. And to what end? if their Ma≈øter could ri≈øe again, what need they come hither? if not, they did him no wrong to abandon him.

But why mention we the Re≈øurrection? they came not thither, not to a thought of it. He had indeed foretold
them of it, but they under≈øtood it not: they could not pro≈øecute what they never apprehended; could they hope to make others believe what they could not imagine? Could others grant that feareable, which they e≈øteemed impo≈ø≈øible? or had they once belief, yet they for≈øook it when they for≈øook their Ma≈øter. They were beaten from it in Geth≈øemane, where but one of the Jews received any lo≈ø≈øe, and he but of one of his eares, and that re≈øtored again; but they all lo≈øt every one his faith, they lo≈øt their Saviour, and their Souls to boot. They were now as faithle≈øs as their fellow Judas, as
faithle≈øs in their Ma≈øter as he was to him. The Re≈øurrection quite forgot, not onely the thing it ≈øelf, but their Ma≈øters mention of it: and therefore they embalm his dead body, and do entombe it as forlorn. The Priests them≈øelves believed more then the Di≈øciples: they feared it, and therefore fortified the Sepulcher; but the Di≈øciples did not ≈øo much as hope. And when he was ri≈øen de facto, they could not believe it, though the women avouched it: „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the womens talk ≈øeemes an old Wives tale, when they tell the Di≈øciples of the Re≈øurrection. Thomas will not
tru≈øt his own eyes though he ≈øee, and his eares though he hear him. Had they any by-intent, they would have been very forward to report and ≈øpread the fame; but they ≈øtood mute at it, and began to ≈øpread them≈øelves each man what way his fancy led him: the fame of the Re≈øurrection did not fright them. And how came the newes abroad? who told it to the high Prie≈øts? not his Di≈øciples, nor the women, but the Souldiers here them≈øelves. But why ≈øtand we to defend the Di≈øciples in a fact never committed? no ≈øuch thing done as they objected. He was not ≈øtole away
at all; My ≈øecond Contradictorie.

Nor by the Di≈øciples, nor by any el≈øe, unle≈øs men were mad, or weary of their lives. The advantage of the Act could no way recompence the danger. The Lawes ≈øo ≈øtrict for medling with Sepulchers, that they could expect no le≈ø≈øe then to incur the crime of Sacriledge; which may be ≈øeen at large in the Dige≈øts de Sepulchro violato: which Lawes, though ≈øince compiled, yet for the mo≈øt part were then and there in force, the Jews being under the Roman Juri≈ødiction. And though they ≈øhould plead that they did
onely tran≈ølate the body, not abu≈øe it, yet they could not avoid the Objection of dolus malus, and ≈øo incur an arbitrary cen≈øure, which would be layd very heavily upon them, things running as they did again≈øt our Saviour. What fair Interpretation could they look for on his behalf, when he him≈øelf was charged with Trea≈øon, for asking a peny to pay tribute? Or if ≈øome had the will to ≈øteal him, yet none had the power or meanes to perform it. The Watch there, termed Souldiers, were of a middle nature between Souldiers and Hangmen; Spiculatores, they carried a ≈øpeare in their hands, but a
halter at their girdles, alwayes ready for any deadly ≈øervice. They were „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Satellites, a Guard to the Governour; and Cu≈øtodes, Jaylours, Warders for Pri≈øoners; and Vigiles, Watchers for their bodies who ≈øuffered: the common Executioners of corporal puni≈øhment, whether it reached onely to ≈øen≈øe, or forward to life. To expre≈øs their Roman nature home, the Ea≈øtern Nation borrowed Language from the We≈øtern, the Greeks from the Latine, Cu≈øtodia; and the Syriaque, as Ma≈øter Fuller ob≈øerves, from Quae≈øtionarij, Officers ad quae≈øtionem & inqui≈øitionem, Que≈øtioners or Inqui≈øitors, Tormentors,
or Serjeants of the Rack, to extort Confe≈øsions in criminal Examinations. At the peril of their life it was, if the party under their execution did not endure the extremity of the Law. If the Pri≈øoner e≈øcaped with no puni≈øhment, or with le≈ø≈øe, or in ultimo ≈øupplicio recovered by his life, or his dead body otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed then the Lawes ordained or permitted, then were tho≈øe Souldiers to take the room of the Pri≈øoners, to be wa≈øted and ≈øpent out upon the ≈øame puni≈øhment whereto the Pri≈øoner was liable; Eju≈ømodi paena con≈øumendi, the very words of the Law. Could any man now imagine the
Watch could now be either ≈øo carele≈øs, or ≈øuch Cowards as to let our Saviour to be ≈øtole away? Men dur≈øt as well have fetcht him from the Cro≈ø≈øe as from the Grave.

But ≈øay that they were ≈øuch maimed Souldiers, as that they had neither eye to watch, nor heart to ward; yet the Sepulcher it ≈øelf was ≈øo impregnable, that it alone would ≈øecure the body. There could be no burglary, nor breaking it up, no undermining; The Soyl was Pick-axe proof, a firm Rock ≈øpred out of the Roots of Golgotha, gabion'd and rough-ca≈øt with flint. No

The manner of his re≈øurrection ≈øo miraculous and ineffable, that bad words expre≈øs it be≈øt. In a moral relation to the Jewes, it is here
